content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The image displays six discrete pieces of tissue, which are consistent in appearance with lymph nodes embedded in adipose tissue. The lymph nodes vary in size and staining intensity. Most have a classic ovoid shape with a dense, basophilic (purple) cellular component. Some nodes appear to have preserved architecture with lighter-staining germinal centers, while others look more diffusely and darkly stained, which could suggest effacement by a metastatic process. The overall impression is that these are regional lymph nodes being assessed for cancer metastasis.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, I would systematically examine every lymph node, paying close attention to the periphery, specifically the capsule and the subcapsular sinus. This is the first place metastatic cells typically lodge. The zoomed-in area is on the edge of the lymph node on the left side of the image (third from the top). I would zoom in here to carefully assess the interface between the lymphoid tissue and the surrounding pericapsular fat. This is a critical step to identify small metastatic deposits or evidence of extranodal extension, which is when the tumor breaks through the lymph node capsule. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining each lymph node on the slide to look for evidence of metastasis. The green box highlights the periphery of the lymph node located on the far left of the image. I would zoom into this specific area because the lymph node capsule and the subcapsular sinus (the area just beneath the capsule) are the initial sites where metastatic tumor cells, arriving via afferent lymphatic vessels, typically deposit. It is a critical area to scrutinize for early metastatic disease. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the first lymph node, located at the top-left of the slide, to begin a systematic review. The specific area of interest, highlighted by the green box, is the subcapsular region. At low power, this area appears subtly paler and more eosinophilic (pink) than the surrounding dense lymphoid parenchyma. The subcapsular sinus is the most common initial site for metastatic tumor cells to deposit in a lymph node, so any architectural or cytologic abnormality in this location is highly suspicious and requires immediate high-magnification assessment. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the periphery of the first lymph node from the top-left. This specific area corresponds to the subcapsular sinus, which is the initial site where metastatic tumor cells arriving via lymphatic vessels typically lodge. Any irregularity in the architecture or color in this region at low power, such as the slight paleness seen here, requires high-power evaluation to rule out or confirm metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area, which corresponds to the lymph node in the upper left quadrant, as part of a systematic examination of all submitted lymph nodes. This particular node shows prominent nodularity (follicles) at low power. It is crucial to examine these structures at higher magnification to differentiate between benign reactive follicular hyperplasia and potential metastatic deposits, particularly subtle micrometastases that might be present in the subcapsular sinus or within the lymphoid parenchyma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. This is the large, centrally located lymph node on the slide, making it a logical starting point for a systematic review. I am zooming into the parenchyma of the node to assess its architecture and cellular composition at high power. The goal is to determine if the normal lymph node structure is preserved or if it is effaced or infiltrated by metastatic tumor cells, which would appear as foreign, atypical epithelial cells, often forming glands or nests. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the lymph node in the upper right because its architecture appears disrupted at low magnification. Unlike the other nodes which have a more uniform appearance, this one has patchy areas that are less basophilic (less purple). This heterogeneity is a key feature that raises suspicion for infiltration by metastatic carcinoma, which often replaces the normal lymphoid tissue with clusters of tumor cells. The goal is to examine this area at high power to confirm or rule out the presence of metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining all submitted lymph nodes for evidence of metastasis. The lymph node in the upper right (the first one from the top right) catches my attention because its contour is irregular, and there seems to be a paler, less organized area at its edge, contrasting with the more uniform, dense lymphoid tissue. This architectural effacement is highly suspicious for metastatic infiltration, which often begins in the subcapsular sinus. Therefore, a closer look at this specific area is crucial to identify or rule out the presence of tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the lymph node in the upper right because its appearance at low magnification is highly suspicious for metastasis. Unlike the other nodes which appear more uniform, this one shows architectural effacement and an irregular interface with the perinodal fat. The primary task is to identify positive lymph nodes, and this one is the most likely candidate based on the initial overview. I want to examine the cellular details at the edge of the node to confirm the presence of tumor cells and assess for extracapsular extension. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining all the lymph nodes for evidence of metastasis. I've chosen to zoom into the lymph node at the bottom right of the slide. At low power, this node displays architectural disruption. There are pale, irregular structures expanding what appears to be the sinusoids. This pattern is suspicious for infiltration by tumor cells, which often travel through and expand the sinuses. I need to magnify this area to assess the cytology of the cells within these structures to differentiate between reactive changes (like sinus histiocytosis) and metastatic carcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the lymph node located in the bottom right of the thumbnail. The reason for focusing on this specific area is the visible irregularity at the periphery of the node. Even at low magnification, the border between the lymphoid tissue and the surrounding fat appears disrupted and indistinct, and there is a subtle change in color from the dense purple of the lymphocytes to a lighter, more eosinophilic hue. This pattern is highly suspicious for metastatic tumor infiltration, particularly in the subcapsular sinus, and potential extranodal extension. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining each lymph node for evidence of metastasis. I zoomed into the lymph node in the bottom right quadrant because, at low power, it shows a clear architectural abnormality. The subcapsular and cortical areas appear expanded and have a different color and texture compared to normal lymphoid tissue. This pattern is highly suspicious for infiltration by carcinoma, so I need to examine it at high magnification to confirm the presence of tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, there is a clear distinction between two cell populations. On the right, there are sheets of small, dark, round cells, which are native lymphocytes of the lymph node. In the center and extending to the left and bottom, there is an infiltrate of larger, atypical cells with more eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm and irregular, pleomorphic nuclei. These atypical cells are arranged in poorly formed, infiltrative glands and nests. The infiltrate is seen extending into the surrounding adipose tissue (seen as empty white circles). My impression is that this is metastatic adenocarcinoma, confirming this is a positive lymph node. The presence of tumor cells in the pericapsular fat indicates extranodal extension, which is an important prognostic factor.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I can clearly see the interface between the lymph node and the surrounding tissue. On the right, there is dense lymphoid tissue composed of small, mature-appearing lymphocytes. In the center, there is a pink, fibrous lymph node capsule. On the left, there is perinodal tissue consisting of mature adipocytes (fat cells) and fibrovascular tissue. I am carefully examining the subcapsular sinus for atypical cells or glandular structures, which would indicate metastasis. In this particular field, I do not see any tumor cells. The capsule appears intact and the sinus is clear. My impression of this specific area is that it is negative for metastasis; it shows a benign lymph node capsule and adjacent parenchyma.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, there is a clear demarcation between two cell populations. The lower portion of the image shows the native lymph node parenchyma, composed of a dense population of small, round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm. In contrast, the upper portion, located in the subcapsular sinus, shows a cluster of atypical epithelial cells. These cells are much larger, have abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, and large, pleomorphic, vesicular nuclei with prominent nucleoli. They are arranged in poorly-formed glandular structures and nests. My impression is that these features are diagnostic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. Therefore, this is a positive lymph node.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

At high power, I can clearly see the lymph node capsule and the subcapsular sinus. There is an infiltrate of atypical epithelial cells within the fibrous tissue of the capsule and extending into the sinus. These cells are larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, have pleomorphic nuclei, and form irregular clusters and glands. This morphology is consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma, confirming that this is a positive lymph node.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see lymphoid tissue characterized by prominent lymphoid follicles. These follicles exhibit features of reactive germinal centers, containing a mixed population of centroblasts, centrocytes, and scattered tingible body macrophages. The surrounding mantle zones and interfollicular areas are composed of small, mature-appearing lymphocytes. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or nests of tumor cells to suggest metastasis. My impression is that this is a benign reactive lymph node showing follicular hyperplasia, and it is negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see a dense and crowded population of lymphoid cells. There are preserved, albeit hyperplastic, lymphoid follicles, which are the rounder, more organized structures. I do not see any clear evidence of metastatic carcinoma, such as atypical glands, nests of epithelial cells with large irregular nuclei, or a desmoplastic stromal response. The white spaces are artifacts from tissue processing. My impression of this specific area is that it shows reactive follicular hyperplasia, suggesting the node is likely negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, the left side of the image shows mature adipose tissue, representing the perinodal fat. The right side shows the lymph node parenchyma. The normal lymphoid tissue is extensively infiltrated and replaced by irregular nests and clusters of malignant cells. These cells are larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, have more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and pleomorphic, hyperchromatic nuclei. This morphology is characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic carcinoma.
This is ROI 8 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view confirms the suspicion of metastasis. At the top of the image is perinodal adipose tissue. Below it, within the lymph node parenchyma, there are nests and clusters of atypical epithelial cells. These cells are larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, have more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and large, irregular, hyperchromatic nuclei. They are infiltrating the subcapsular region and the cortex of the node. The native lymphoid follicles are still visible deeper in the tissue. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 9 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in area, I can clearly see residual lymphoid tissue, characterized by dense sheets of small, dark lymphocytes. However, this is heavily infiltrated by atypical glandular structures. These glands are irregular, sometimes fused or cribriform, and are lined by malignant epithelial cells with large, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei. This morphology is consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma, likely originating from the colorectal primary. The tumor appears to be infiltrating into the surrounding adipose tissue on the right side of the image, which would indicate extracapsular extension. My impression is a positive lymph node with metastatic adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 10 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?
No impression available.
This is ROI 11 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I can clearly see the interface between the lymph node and the surrounding tissue. On the right is the dense, native lymphoid tissue composed of small, dark lymphocytes. Infiltrating the subcapsular region and extending into the perinodal fat on the left are clusters and nests of atypical cells. These cells are larger than the lymphocytes, have more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and pleomorphic nuclei. This is a classic presentation of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic carcinoma, consistent with a colorectal primary.
This is ROI 12 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I can see the normal lymphoid parenchyma being infiltrated by malignant cells. There are nests and poorly formed glands composed of atypical cells with large, irregular, hyperchromatic nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm. This morphology is characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. Therefore, my impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic colorectal cancer.
